title: In-class Ex01
text:
In the code chunk below, ‘p_load()’ of pacman package is used to load tidyverse family of package

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)


realis <-read.csv("data/realis2019.csv")
head(realis, 10)

title: About
text:
About this site

### This is about but no about

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
The code chunk below uses p-load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)





exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

Rows: 322 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): ID, CLASS, GENDER, RACE
dbl (3): ENGLISH, MATHS, SCIENCE

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
The code chunk below uses p-load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

Rows: 322 Columns: 7
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): ID, CLASS, GENDER, RACE
dbl (3): ENGLISH, MATHS, SCIENCE

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.1 Dotplot(with y-axis)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize = 0.5)

Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with
`binwidth`.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.2 Dotplot(turn-off y-axis)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth = 2.5,
               dotsize = 0.5) +
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,
                     breaks = NULL)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.3 Histogram (default bin is 30)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram()

`stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.4 Histogram (changeing geom())

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 color = "black",
                 fill = "light blue")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.5 Histogram (changeing aes())

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = ENGLISH,
           fill = GENDER)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 color = "grey30")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.6 Density

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = ENGLISH,
           color = CLASS)) +
  geom_density()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.7 Boxplot (with notch)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(y = ENGLISH,
           x = GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch = TRUE)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.8 Violin (Comparing multiple data distribution)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(y = ENGLISH,
           x = GENDER)) +
  geom_violin()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
3.9 Point

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = ENGLISH,
           y = MATHS)) +
  geom_point()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: 3.10 Combine (“jitter” refers to a technique used to add small random bariation to data points)
text:
3.10 Combine (“jitter” refers to a technique used to add small random bariation to data points)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(y = ENGLISH,
           x = GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(position = "jitter",
             size = 0.5)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
4.1 (Before)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(y = ENGLISH, x = GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
4.2 Stat (After)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(y = ENGLISH,
           x = GENDER)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",
               fun.y = "mean",
               colour = "red",
               size = 4)

Warning: The `fun.y` argument of `stat_summary()` is deprecated as of ggplot2 3.3.0.
ℹ Please use the `fun` argument instead.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
4.3 Add curve on a scatterplot

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(y = ENGLISH, x = MATHS)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(size = 0.5)

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
4.4 Facet_wrap

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20) +
  facet_wrap(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
4.5 Facet_grid

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20) +
  facet_grid(~ CLASS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
5.1 (before)

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
5.2 Working with coordinate (after)

ggplot(data=exam_data, 
       aes(x=RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: 5.3 Changing the y- and x-axis range (before)
text:
5.3 Changing the y- and x-axis range (before)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, size=0.5)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: 5.4 Changing the y- and x-axis range (after)
text:
5.4 Changing the y- and x-axis range (after)

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, size=0.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100))

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
6.1 Classic

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_classic()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
6.2 Minimal

ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = RACE)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal()

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, ggthemes,
               hrbrthemes, tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)






exam_data <- read.csv("data/Exam_data.csv")








ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, size = 0.5) +
  geom_label(aes(label = ID),
             hjust = 0.5,
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, size = 0.5) +
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID),
             hjust = 0.5,
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'


Warning: ggrepel: 318 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider
increasing max.overlaps




















ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_gray() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")








ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_bw() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")








ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_classic() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")








ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_dark() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")








ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_light() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")








ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_linedraw() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")








ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_minimal() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")








ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  theme_void() +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")











ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100, color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_economist()











ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum()








ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum(axis_title_size = 18,
              base_size = 15,
              grid = "Y")












p1 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")





p2 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25", fill = "grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")





p3 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
             aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, 
              size = .5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100), ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")





p1



p2



p3

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'












p1 + p2








(p1/p2)|p3

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









(p1/p2)|p3 +
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = "I")

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









p3 + inset_element(p2,
                   left = 0.02,
                   bottom = 0.7,
                   right = 0.5,
                   top = 1)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









patchwork <- (p1/p2)|p3 
patchwork & theme_economist()

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, ggthemes,
               hrbrthemes, tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text: exam_data <- read.csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, size = 0.5) +
  geom_label(aes(label = ID),
             hjust = 0.5,
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'








ggplot(data = exam_data,
       aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, size = 0.5) +
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID),
             hjust = 0.5,
             vjust = -.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100),
                  ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'


Warning: ggrepel: 318 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider
increasing max.overlaps

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
p1 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25",
                 fill = "grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25", fill = "grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")





p3 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,
             aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, 
              size = .5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0,100), ylim = c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")





p1



p2



p3

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

text:

  plot_annotation(tag_levels = "I")

                   left = 0.02,
                   bottom = 0.7,
                   right = 0.5,
                   top = 1)

title: ISSS608-VAA
text: Welcome to ISSS608 Visual Analytics and Applications homepage. In this website, you will find my coursework prepared for this course.

title: Take-home Exercise 1
text:
There are two major residential property market in Singapore, namely public and private housing. Public housing aims to meet the basic need of the general public with monthly household income less than or equal to S$14,000. For families with monthly household income more than S$14,000, they need to turn to the private residential market.
We will go to prepare minimum two and maximum three data visualisation to reveal the private residential market and sub-markets of Singapore for the 1st quarter of 2024.







transaction_data_2024Q1 <- read.csv("data-2/2024Q1.csv")








According to the transaction_data_2024Q1, there are 4722 obs. of 21 variables before we make a data cleaning.

Now we need to check the duplicate.
